author: By Gary Phillips
title: Yankees Head to the All-Star Break Looking as Dominant as Ever
description: A pair of blowout wins over the rival Boston Red Sox helped the Yankees shake off the closest thing they’ve had to a slump all year.
content: Aaron Boone is ready to trade in his pinstripes for board shorts and a spatula, at least for a few days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Prime Minister Race in Britain Remains Unsettled in Wake of Johnson’s Downfall
description: Rishi Sunak, the former chancellor of the Exchequer, is the current front-runner, but Penny Mordaunt, a junior trade minister, is making a surprisingly strong run for the leadership position.
content: LONDON — The last time Britain’s Conservative Party elected a new leader, Boris Johnson dominated the contest from wire to wire, a political celebrity so famous that many voters just called him Boris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Why Union Drives Are Succeeding
description: College-educated workers are driving a spike in union organizing.
content: After decades of declining union membership, organized labor may be on the verge of a resurgence in the U.S. Employees seeking better working conditions and higher pay have recently organized unions at Starbucks, Amazon, Apple and elsewhere. Applications for union elections this year are on pace to approach their highest level in a decade. I asked Noam Scheiber, who covers workers and labor issues for The Times, what’s behind the latest flurry of union activity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaly Soto
title: Extreme Heat Continues Its March Across Western Europe
description: A heat wave that has caused fires to rage in southwestern France and Spain is moving north toward Britain, which may see its highest recorded temperatures ever.
content: LONDON — The weather maps for Europe were blood red on Sunday as heat that has been baking Spain and Italy and fanning fires in southwest France worked its way north toward Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Fred Kerley Leads U.S. Sweep in 100 Meters at Worlds
description: Kerley won the gold and was followed by Marvin Bracy-Williams and Trayvon Bromell.
content: Fred Kerley did not know that he was the fastest man in the world when he crossed the finish line at Hayward Field on Saturday night. Like so much else in his life, he needed to wait and wonder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola, Kris Rhim and Matthew Futterman
title: Here’s what to watch at the world championships on Sunday.
description: Watch the men’s shot put and the fastest women in the world in the evening.
content: Watch the men’s shot put and the fastest women in the world in the evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Meet the New Voice of Baseball
description: Joe Davis inherited Vin Scully’s job with the Dodgers. Now, he will replace Joe Buck at the All-Star Game and the World Series. He has done his homework, and he’s ready to shine.
content: LOS ANGELES — The basketball game was postponed in the morning, meaning Joe Davis would not be on the air in the afternoon. This was in January in Ann Arbor, Mich., not far from his childhood home, but Davis kept his evening flight and headed early to the airport. If he could not call a game, why pass up a free day to study?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Briefing: In Mideast, Biden Eyes China and Russia
description: Also, a heat wave is sweeping across Europe and Egypt is jailing political prisoners.
content: In a series of encounters with Arab strongmen in Saudi Arabia this weekend, President Biden emphasized why he was strengthening ties with allies he had previously criticized for anti-democratic behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: ‘He’s Built for New York’
description: Only 21, Anthony Volpe is so talented that the Yankees were willing to let members of the greatest free-agent class of shortstops all land elsewhere.
content: LOS ANGELES — Entering this season, the Yankees had a gaping hole at shortstop. Gleyber Torres had struggled there and was moving back to second base. The Yankees were in luck, though, as a heralded free-agent class of shortstops was hitting the free-agent market: Carlos Correa, Corey Seager, Trevor Story and Javier Báez had all been All-Stars, and three of them had won a World Series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Books That Immerse Me in a Better World
description: A conversation with Karina Yan Glaser, who writes middle-grade books set in a Harlem where kids can roam and neighbors know one another’s names.
content: We’re in the hot, slow days of summer, that stretch where kids are getting bored and parents start counting down the days till school begins again. When the days feel lazy and long, there is no better time to reach for a book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Week in Business: Twitter Hits Back
description: Inflation in June was high. The euro tumbled to parity with the U.S. dollar. And central banks around the world are raising interest rates.
content: In Elon Musk’s saga with Twitter, the end of one chapter is just the start of another. Shortly after signaling that he was backing out of his deal to buy the social media company, Mr. Musk was sued by Twitter. The company accused him of “knowingly, intentionally, willfully and materially” breaching their agreement. Mr. Musk’s lawyers said on Friday that Twitter’s request in the suit for an expedited trial in September was unreasonable and asked to delay it. When, and if, the case goes to trial, a judge in Delaware’s Court of Chancery will decide whether Mr. Musk’s claims that Twitter withheld information about spam accounts on the site are valid. The two parties could also settle, with Mr. Musk paying damages. Or, if his financing falls through, he could get out of the deal by paying a $1 billion breakup fee. Another possibility still is that Mr. Musk’s threat to walk away spooks Twitter into renegotiating with him, which could result in his buying the company at a discount. Worried shareholders will hear about how much damage Mr. Musk may have done when Twitter releases its second-quarter earnings this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Griner Case Draws Attention to ‘Wrongful Detentions’
description: Dozens of Americans are believed to be held by foreign adversaries as political pawns in disputes with the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — Brittney Griner. Austin Tice. The Citgo 6. And now, potentially, three American military veterans who were captured by enemy forces after traveling to Ukraine to fight Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Jewelry and Gems Worth Millions Stolen From Brink’s Truck in California
description: The value of the missing merchandise, which was headed last week to an International Gem and Jewelry Show event, was unclear. One conservative figure put the value at up to $10 million.
content: Jewelry and gems worth millions — a conservative figure put the value at up to $10 million — were stolen from a Brink’s armored truck near Los Angeles last week, the security company said, leaving some victims wondering how such a theft could have occurred.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 17, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 17, 2022.
content: An article on Page 24 this weekend about planting trees to fight climate change refers imprecisely to an action taken by Elon Musk. He changed his Twitter display name to “Treelon,” not his Twitter handle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: A Crop of New Novels About Race and Racism Finds Freedom in Satire
description: Authors of color have turned in recent books to humor and surreal conceits to explore racism, identity politics and the pain of being “on the other side of whiteness.”
content: In Chinelo Okparanta’s new novel, a young white man is disgusted by his bigoted, small-town parents. Some of his reactions are typical: He disavows their views and moves to New York City. Others, though, are decidedly strange: He starts calling himself G-Dawg, joins a self-help group for white people ashamed of their race — and begins to identify as a Black man from Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: All Dolled Up for the Heat
description: Parties were held for the contemporary art market Platform and the Parrish Art Museum.
content: “We don’t sell NFTs, and we won’t,” said Bettina Huang, co-founder of Platform, an online marketplace for contemporary art that celebrated its first anniversary on Wednesday at the Bowery Hotel. The website, also co-founded by David Zwirner’s two children, Marlene and Lucas Zwirner, showcases artists from smaller galleries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: A North Dakota City Attracted a Corn Mill. Then Came Questions About Its Chinese Owners.
description: Officials in Grand Forks are enthusiastic about the potential benefit to the economy, but the connection to China stoked a backlash.
content: GRAND FORKS, N.D. — For years, the leaders of Grand Forks had their eyes on a patch of cropland north of town, not far from a pasta-making facility, a potato processor and a state-owned flour mill where farmers received top dollar for their wheat. That muddy field, they thought, would be the perfect place for another agriculture business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: David Weiss Halivni, Controversial Talmudic Scholar, Dies at 94
description: He was considered too radical by many Orthodox rabbis and too regressive by many Conservative Jewish leaders. But his work was widely praised.
content: Rabbi David Weiss Halivni, a renowned scholar of the Talmud who started studying its labyrinthine arguments when he was 5 and devoted much of his life to the controversial idea that it was riddled with inconsistencies and incongruities that required further inquiry and reconciling to sustain its divine authority, died on June 28 at his home in Jerusalem. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: In ‘Between the Lines,’ Romance Is Thwarted by Reality
description: A new Off Broadway musical, based on the best-selling young adult novel by Jodi Picoult and Samantha van Leer, is uneven but sweet, our critic writes.
content: What a tricky business adaptations are. A musical based on a novel can never be the same as its source material, and it isn’t meant to be. But throw out too many of the original elements and you leave an audience wondering how you lost your way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: In the Face of Fact, the Supreme Court Chose Faith
description: Kennedy v. Bremerton School District reflects the conservative majority’s brazen efforts to inflict its political and religious agenda on the rest of the country.
content: Imagine your boss fervently proclaiming his religious beliefs at the end of a companywide meeting, inviting everyone on the team who shares those beliefs to join in. You’re surrounded by colleagues and other higher-ups. Everyone is watching to see who participates and who holds back, knowing that whatever each of you does could make or break your job and even your career, whether you share his convictions or not. But hey, totally up to you!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck Have a Low-Key Midnight Wedding in Las Vegas
description: The superstar couple, who got back together last year, waited in line and went to a chapel that Lopez said “graciously stayed open” a few minutes past midnight so they could wed.
content: The superstar couple of Ben Affleck and Jennifer Lopez, whose on-and-off relationship has garnered plenty of media attention since the early 2000s, married in Las Vegas on Saturday, according to Lopez and a court document.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Eshe Nelson
title: Global Central Banks Ramp Up Inflation Fight
description: Central banks in the U.S., Europe, Canada and parts of Asia are lifting interest rates rapidly as they try to wrestle breakneck inflation under control.
content: Central bankers around the world are lifting interest rates at an aggressive clip as rapid inflation persists and seeps into a broad array of goods and services, setting the global economy up for a lurch toward more expensive credit, lower stock and bond values and — potentially — a sharp pullback in economic activity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Lend Me a Jukebox Opera. Yuks and Tenor Required.
description: “Let’s do a Rossini comedy that doesn’t exist yet,” the head of the Glimmerglass Festival said. Coming soon: Ken Ludwig’s “Tenor Overboard.”
content: Comic operas tend to be crowd-pleasers: At last, a break from all the tragic deaths and doomed lovers. The problem is there aren’t that many to choose from. Opera companies can program “Così Fan Tutte,” “Il Barbiere di Siviglia” or “L’Elisir d’Amore” and a handful of others only so many times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: It’s Hardly Any Matter at All
description: Phoebe Gordon makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Bear with us for a few days, solvers, as Rachel Fabi pedals across a healthy portion of New York State. And congratulations to Phoebe Gordon, who makes her New York Times crossword debut with a light and lovely theme in a clean Monday grid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Netflix, Still Reeling, Bets Big on ‘The Gray Man’
description: The streaming service hopes its latest release can be the start of a blockbuster franchise that attracts much-needed subscribers.
content: Anthony and Joe Russo like to go big.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: Jamaica’s women have taken over sprints. It’s another story for the men.
description: Jamaican women have taken over the sprints. Jamaican men, meanwhile, have become an afterthought on the global track and field stage.
content: As Usain Bolt, Yohan Blake and Warren Weir posed for photos with the Jamaican flag draped around their backs after a sweep of the 200-meter final at the 2012 Olympics, Jamaica’s dominance in men’s sprinting seemed like it would be interminable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Billy Crystal’s ‘Mr. Saturday Night’ Will End Its Broadway Run
description: The stage musical, adapted from a 1992 film, will close Labor Day weekend after five months at the Nederlander Theater.
content: “Mr. Saturday Night,” Billy Crystal’s musical about an aging comedian trying to reboot his career, will end its Broadway run on Labor Day weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: After New Abortion Laws, Some Patients Have Trouble Obtaining Miscarriage Treatment
description: Surgical procedures and medication for miscarriages are identical to those for abortion, and some patients report delayed or denied miscarriage care because doctors and pharmacists fear running afoul of abortion bans.
content: Last year, a 35-year-old woman named Amanda, who lives in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, had a miscarriage in the first trimester of her pregnancy. At a large hospital, a doctor performed a surgical procedure often used as a safe and quick method to remove tissue from a failed pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Family Members Mourn a 4-Year-Old Girl Killed in Russian Missile Attack
description: The death of Liza Dmytriyeva, a 4-year-old with Down syndrome, encapsulated the brutality of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: The family and friends of Liza Dmytriyeva brushed away tears on Sunday as four men carried her coffin into the cathedral, where a photo of the smiling girl was nestled between roses and teddy bears three days after she was killed by a Russian cruise missile strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Ex-NASCAR Driver Robert ‘Bobby’ East Fatally Stabbed at California Gas Station
description: The suspect in the stabbing, Trent William Milsap, 28, was shot dead after the police tried to serve him a warrant on Friday.
content: The former NASCAR driver Robert East, known as Bobby, was fatally stabbed on Wednesday in Westminster, Calif., the authorities said, and the suspect in the stabbing was killed on Friday in “an officer-involved shooting.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Britain Girds for Scorching Heat That Could Break Records
description: Temperatures may top 100 degrees Fahrenheit in some areas, a rarity that has prompted a national emergency.
content: LONDON — Britain was bracing for what could be its hottest day ever recorded. Many schools in England planned to close, hospitals were canceling nonessential procedures and retirement homes were making preparations to keep their vulnerable residents safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dov Fox
title: What Will Happen if Doctors Defy the Law to Provide Abortions?
description: Those who withhold care get conscience protections. What about those who want to provide it?
content: Days after Texas banned most abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy in September 2021, Dr. Alan Braid disclosed that he had “provided an abortion to a woman, who though still in her first trimester, was beyond the state’s new limit.” Dr. Braid wrote in a Washington Post opinion piece that when he was a medical resident before Roe v. Wade, he had seen “teenagers die from illegal abortions. One I will never forget. When she came into the ER, her vaginal cavity was packed with rags. She died a few days later from massive organ failure, caused by a septic infection.” Dr. Braid resolved, “I can’t just sit back and watch us return to 1972.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: Four Killed in New Mexico Helicopter Crash After Responding to Wildfire
description: Three members of a county sheriff’s office and a member of the county’s fire department were returning to Albuquerque after responding to a wildfire.
content: A helicopter returning to Albuquerque after responding to a wildfire in New Mexico crashed, killing three members of the Bernalillo County Sheriff’s Office and a member of the Bernalillo County Fire Department, the authorities said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: Nikolai Krogius, Adviser in Chess ‘Match of the Century,’ Dies at 91
description: A grandmaster and a sports psychologist, he was part of the support team for the world champion Boris Spassky in his 1972 loss to Bobby Fischer.
content: In September 1972, a small group of Russian chess grandmasters headed toward Moscow on a plane, grimly anticipating the reception they would receive there. The group included Boris Spassky, who had just lost the world championship title to Bobby Fischer, the mercurial American player, and Nikolai Krogius, who had been part of the team assisting Mr. Spassky in the match in Reykjavik, Iceland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Two Alligators Fatally Attack Florida Woman After She Falls Into Pond
description: An 80-year-old woman was killed after falling into a pond near her house. It was the second fatal alligator attack in Florida this year.
content: An 80-year-old woman was killed by two alligators after she fell into a pond near her house in Englewood, Fla., on Friday night, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Do Cancer Centers Push Too Many Tests?
description: Studies found that centers provided incomplete or unbalanced information, which could lead to unnecessary screenings and health complications in older adults.
content: Say a postcard arrives in the mail, a reminder to make an appointment for a mammogram. Or a primary care doctor orders a PSA test to screen a man for prostate cancer, or tells him that because of his years of smoking, he should be screened for lung cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Peeling Paint in Hong Kong Reveals Work of Newly Relevant ‘King’
description: When he was alive, the graffiti of Tsang Tsou-choi, or the “King of Kowloon,” was considered peculiar and personal. In a radically changed city, his mostly vanished art now has a political charge.
content: HONG KONG — Often shirtless in summer, smelling of sweat and ink, the aggrieved artist wrote incessantly, and everywhere: on walls, underpasses, lamp posts and traffic light control boxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Jazmine Ulloa
title: As the Planet Cooks, Climate Stalls as a Political Issue
description: Joe Manchin’s rejection of a compromise climate bill tells a familiar story: Voters and politicians put a higher premium on immediate issues, such as inflation and the economy, giving politicians a pass on global warming.
content: Summers in Maricopa County, Ariz., have become at times unbearable, Kyle Hawkinson said on Friday. Smog and haze hung heavily over Phoenix, and residents were bracing for fire season, when the heat and air pollution would only grow worse. Climate change, he said, is at least partly to blame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: 9/11 Families Call on Trump to Cancel Saudi-Backed Golf Event
description: The LIV Golf tournament is set for the end of July at Donald Trump’s Bedminster course in New Jersey.
content: Relatives of people killed on Sept. 11 are urging former President Donald J. Trump to cancel a Saudi-backed golf tournament set to be held this month at Trump National Golf Club Bedminster in New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Shed No Tears for Carolyn Bryant Donham
description: Emmett Till’s accuser said she “always felt like a victim as well as Emmett.” Don’t feel sorry for her.
content: Enough!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and John Ismay
title: As Russia Runs Low on Drones, Iran Plans to Step In, U.S. Officials Say
description: The potential delivery of hundreds of Iranian drones would help the Kremlin replenish a fleet that has suffered steep losses in Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House disclosure last week that Russia is seeking hundreds of armed and unarmed surveillance drones from Iran to use in the war in Ukraine reflects Moscow’s need to both fill a critical battlefield gap and find a long-term supplier of a crucial combat technology, U.S. intelligence, military and independent analysts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis and Cora Engelbrecht
title: Ukrainian Plane Carrying Serbian Munitions Bound for Bangladesh Crashes in Greece
description: Eight Ukrainian citizens were killed when the cargo plane transporting 11.5 tons of weapons crashed in a field in Greece.
content: ATHENS — A Ukrainian cargo plane carrying 11.5 tons of Serbian-made weapons destined for Bangladesh crashed in northern Greece late Saturday, killing eight Ukrainian crew members and setting off an investigation into whether the hazardous material being transported posed a threat to the local population, state and local officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Gerald Shargel, Criminal Defense Lawyer for the Mob, Dies at 77
description: He coupled legal scholarship with courtroom wit to decimate the prosecution’s cases against Mafia bosses.
content: Gerald Shargel, who unapologetically vowed to “do anything that the law will allow” to defend the Mafia bosses, crooked politicians and other miscreants he represented for more than four decades as a savvy criminal lawyer, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Introducing Sunday Opinion
description: Sunday Review, the 11-year-old Opinion section of The New York Times, is getting a new name and new features.
content: For more than a decade, readers of the Sunday print edition of The New York Times have opened the Opinion section, the Sunday Review, to find commentary by marquee names like Maureen Dowd and Ross Douthat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval
title: Report on Uvalde Shooting Finds ‘Systemic Failures’ in Police Response
description: The decision to finally confront the gunman was made by a small group of officers and could have been made far earlier, the report found.
content: HOUSTON — The first comprehensive assessment of the law enforcement response to the deadly school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, found that blame for the failure to swiftly confront the gunman rested not only with the school police chief, but also with the scores of state and federal officers who gathered at the deadly scene but did not act.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Driver Spent the 20-Minute Trip Telling Me Why I Shouldn’t Be Sad’
description: A cool ride home after a breakup, a celebrity sighting with a twist and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: In Rome, a New Museum for Recovered Treasures Before They Return Home
description: The Museum of Rescued Art showcases antiquities that were looted or otherwise lost before they go back to institutions in the regions from which they were taken.
content: ROME — Last month, Italian officials inaugurated a new museum here whose title sets a lofty agenda: the Museo dell’Arte Salvata, or the Museum of Rescued Art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: At the British Open, Another Letdown for Rory McIlroy
description: McIlroy, the 2014 Open winner and a son of Northern Ireland, was a gallery favorite in Scotland. But his streak of major tournament misery will stretch into 2023.
content: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Deep along the back nine of the British Open on Sunday, around the time that word of Cameron Smith’s birdie streak started to seep through the gallery, the spectators began to seem unsure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Risk of Recession Growing, Driven by Tireless Virus
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 17, 2022.
content: “Everyone following the economic situation right now, including central banks, we do not have a clear answer on how to deal with this situation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: A Young Woman’s Wartime Task: Persuading People to Leave Their Homes
description: In phone calls, doorstep conversations and public speeches, Yana Muravinets has tried to convince people that it’s time to leave villages around the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.
content: The first person Yana Muravinets tried to persuade to leave her home near Ukraine’s front lines was a young woman who was five months pregnant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: A Strategic Marathon Ends With a World Championships Record
description: Conditions in Eugene were perfect for a fast marathon. Tamirat Tola of Ethiopia won the race in 2 hours 5 minutes and 36 seconds, a record for the world championships.
content: For 20 miles, the lead pack of a couple dozen men meant the marathon was anybody’s to win. But then Tamirat Tola from Ethiopia put down a surge on an uphill section of the course, and nobody elected to go with him. Tola stretched his lead to over a minute, and finished outside Autzen Stadium at the University of Oregon in 2 hours 5 minutes 36 seconds, a record for the world championships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Mauricio Lima
title: On Donetsk’s Front Line, Small Gains and Losses Impose a Heavy Toll
description: Ukrainian soldiers say they live under almost constant Russian bombardment but dismiss any suggestion that they cede land.
content: DONETSK PROVINCE, Ukraine — Red flames crackled in the golden wheat field, the target of Russian artillery just minutes earlier. Nearby, the commander of a Ukrainian frontline unit was finishing his lunch of pasta from a tin bowl. As more incoming shells exploded in the fields, his men took cover in their bunkers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Cameron Smith Overtakes Rory McIlroy to Win the 150th British Open
description: The Australian turned in a brilliant final round on the Old Course at St. Andrews to finish at 20 under par and capture his first major championship.
content: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The wind, what little there was of it, finally seemed to be blowing Rory McIlroy’s way again at a major championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neelam Bohra
title: Two people were killed on Friday in Colorado flash flooding.
description: Flash flooding in Northern Colorado killed two people on Friday afternoon, according to the Larimer County Sheriff’s Office.
content: Flash flooding in Northern Colorado killed two people on Friday afternoon, according to the Larimer County Sheriff’s Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Why a Middle-Class Lifestyle Remains Out of Reach for So Many
description: Inflation has unmasked the depths of our affordability crisis.
content: June’s just-released inflation data is startling. At 9.1 percent, it’s the highest year-on-year rate we’ve seen since 1981.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Russian Rocket Strike Kills At Least 3 in Northern Ukraine
description: At least three civilians were killed and three more were injured in Chuhuiv, Ukraine, after Russian rockets struck the city, according to the regional police.
content: At least three civilians were killed and three more were injured in Chuhuiv, Ukraine, after Russian rockets struck the city, according to the regional police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Hitt, Jack D'Isidoro, Dan Powell, John Woo, Corey Schreppel and David Mason
title: The Sunday Read: ‘Want to Do Less Time? A Prison Consultant Might Be Able to Help.’
description: For a price, a new breed of fixer is teaching convicts how to reduce their sentence, get placed in a better facility — and make the most of their months behind bars.
content: People heading to court often turn to the internet for guidance. In so doing, many come across the work of Justin Paperny, who dispenses advice on his YouTube channel. His videos offer preparation advice and help manage expectations, while providing defendants information to be able to hold their current lawyers accountable, and to try to negotiate a lighter sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: A marinated chicken for ranch fans, charred eggplant and burrata, and more recipes.
content: Good morning. I thought I was smart to marinate a bunch of chicken thighs in ranch dressing before grilling them for Sunday supper a while back, but of course Ali Slagle was way ahead of me with her much-better-than-mine recipe for pan-seared ranch chicken (above).
source.name: The New York Times

title: American Christians in the Political Arena
description: The rise of the Christian right. Also: Christie Brinkley on nuclear energy; climate refugees; Dobbs and public option; Francis X. Clines.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
